newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee slows decline on roaster support.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee slows decline on roaster support.

text.p: LIFFE coffee futures slowed their decline by Thursday midsession as trade selling found keen roaster buying at the lows.
Traders said while technicals point to more downside potential after the recent sharp sell-off, manufacturer buying on the dips could help the market consolidate at these levels.
Benchmark September sank to an intraday low of $2,060 a tonne, just above its immediate support at $2,040, before ending the morning at $2,100, still a $15 loss.
Front-month July also ended the session with pared losses but managed to steer clear of the closely-watched $2,000 support. It stood at $2,070, down $13, after a low of $2,020.
Dealings were quite slow with the bulk of the activity centred on structure. July/Sept switch was actively-trade at $30.

In the outrights, traders said trade selling was well absorbed by roaster price-fixing. Food giant Nestle was rumoured to make a buying comeback but the volume was far less aggressive that last's week buying spree.
Nestle is said to be looking for a large share of the Mexican robusta imports recently approved by the government.
The company is the leader in the soluble market in the country. The government had allowed import of up to 150,000 bags of robustas to help fill in a supply gap.
New York's nearby arabica futures prices stayed low by the close on Wednesday on news of Colombia opening "unlimited" coffee sales for July to August.
On the weather front, no damaging cold was expected for Brazil's coffee growing regions this weekend although cooling temperatures to between below and well below normal levels were predicted.
The last severe frosts in 1994, one in June and another in July, devastated Brazilian crop and sent world prices spiralling.
